A Song of Ascents.
In my great distress I called to Adonoy
and He answered me.
Adonoy,
deliver my soul from lying lips,
from a deceitful tongue.
What will He give you
and what more will He add
to a deceitful tongue?
Sharp arrows of a warrior
with burning coals of a broom.
Woe is me that I dwell in Meschech,
that I reside among Kedar's tents.
Too long has my soul dwelt
with those who hate peace.
I am for peace;
but when I speak
they are for war.
Psalm 121
<small>Without complete trust in God's deliverance, spiritual ascent is virtually im- possible. Thus David proclaims Israel's total faith in God.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
I will lift my eyes to the mountains:
from where will my help come?
My help comes from Adonoy,
Maker of heaven and earth.
He will not let your foot slip,
He will not slumber—your Guardian.
Behold, He does not slumber
nor does He sleep—the Guardian of Israel!
Adonoy is your Guardian,
Adonoy is your shelter at your right hand.
By day the sun will not smite you,
nor the moon at night.
Adonoy will guard you from all evil;
He will preserve your soul.
Adonoy will guard your going and coming,
from now and forever.
Psalm 122
<small>We must never forget Jerusalem, our spiritual home, and we must constantly recall and cherish the memories of the House of God.</small>
A Song of Ascents of David.
I rejoiced when they said to me,
“To the House of Adonoy let us go.”
Our feet stood
within your gates, Jerusalem.
Jerusalem which is built
as a city that fosters togetherness.
There the tribes went up,
the tribes of God,
as a testimony of Israel;
to give thanks to the Name of Adonoy.
For there,
were set thrones for judgment,
thrones of the House of David.
Inquire after the peace of Jerusalem;
may those who love you enjoy serenity.
Peace be within your walls,
serenity within your palaces.
For the sake of my brethren and companions,
I will say, “Peace be with you.”
For the sake of the House of Adonoy
our God,
I will seek your good.
Psalm 123
<small>In this Psalm we pray for God's compassion, declaring that our eyes are lifted to him as our sole source of help.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
To You I will lift my eyes,
[to You] Who dwells in heaven.
Behold, as the eyes of servants [look]
toward the hand of their master,
as the eyes of a maiden [look]
toward the hand of her mistress;
so our eyes [look] toward Adonoy our God
until he is gracious to us.
Be gracious to us, Adonoy, be gracious to us
for we are fully satiated with humiliation.
Our soul is fully satiated
with the scorning of those who are at ease,
with the humiliation
of the arrogant oppressors.
Psalm 124

<small>Israel openly declares that it owes its survival through centuries of suffering to God and to God alone, and that the history of its exile has been a demonstra- tion of God's rule and Presence on earth.</small>
A Song of Ascents of David.
“Had it not been for Adonoy
Who was for us,”
let Israel now say.
“Had it not been for Adonoy
Who was for us,
when men rose up against us.
They would have then swallowed us alive,
when their wrath blazed against us.
The waters would have then swept us away,
affliction would have passed over our soul.
Then over our soul would have gone
the impetuous waters.
Blessed is Adonoy,
Who did not give us
as prey to their teeth.
Our soul escaped as a bird
out of the fowler's snare;
the snare is broken and we escaped.
Our help is in the Name of Adonoy,
Maker of heaven and earth.”
Psalm 125
<small>This Psalm expounds the theme of our trust in God. It proclaims that through God's Divine protection, which visibly accompanied Israel at all times, we have found security.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
Those who trust in Adonoy
are as Mount Zion which cannot be moved,
but abides forever.
Jerusalem is surrounded by mountains,
and Adonoy is around His people,
from now forever.
For it will not rest [for long]
the reign of wickedness
upon the lot of the righteous;
in order that the righteous will not put forth
their hands unto iniquity.
Do good, Adonoy, to those who are good,
and to those who are upright in their hearts.
And as for those who turn aside
to their crooked ways,
Adonoy will lead them away
together with the workers of iniquity;
peace be upon Israel.
Psalm 126
<small>This Psalm voices the hope of our ultimate return to Zion when our tears of sorrow will become tears of joy.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
When Adonoy brings about
the return to Zion
we will have been like dreamers.
Then
will our mouths be filled with laughter,
and our tongue with joyous song.
Then they will say among the nations:
‘Adonoy has done great things for them.'
Adonoy had done great things for us;
we will [then] rejoice.
Adonoy! bring back our exiles
like springs in the desert.
Those who sow in tears
will reap with joyous song.
[Though] he walks along weeping,
carrying the bag of seed,
he will return with joyous song
carrying his sheaves.
Psalm 127

<small>In this Psalm David instructs Solomon, his son, on the virtues of proper training for children. The arrow shot from a strong hand bears within itself the strength of the bowman long after it has left his hand, and it follows unswervingly the direction given by the hand of the mighty man. So, too, children raised by dedicated parents will remain unwaveringly and unhesitat- ingly true to the goal set for them by the guiding hands of parents, long after they have left the immediate sphere of that parental guidance.</small>
A Song of Ascents of Solomon.
If Adonoy will not build a house,
then in vain have its builders toiled upon it;
if Adonoy will not preserve the city,
in vain does the watchman keep vigil.
It is in vain for you
that you rise early, sit up late,
who eat the bread of toil;
but He will surely give [sustenance]
to His loved ones
to those who banish sleep from themselves.
Behold, a heritage of Adonoy, are children
a reward [from Him] is the fruit of the womb.
As arrows in the hand of a mighty man,
so are the children of one's youth.
Fortunate is the man
who has filled his quiver with them;
they will not be ashamed
when they speak with their enemies
in the gate.
Psalm 128
<small>Fortunate is the home permeated with fear of God, and crowned with prosperity and contentment.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
Fortunate is everyone who fears Adonoy,
who walks in His ways.
The toil of your hands,
when you eat thereof—
fortunate are you, good will be yours.
Your wife is a fruitful vine
in the innermost parts of your home,
your children are like olive plants
around your table.
Behold, so is blessed the man
who fears Adonoy.
May Adonoy bless you out of Zion,
and may you look
upon the good of Jerusalem
all the days of your life.
May you see [the] children of your children,
peace upon Israel.
Psalm 129

<small>This Psalm describes the fleeting pleasures, devoid of blessing or permanence, of those who hate Zion and who fight against the Torah which comes forth from Zion, and against Israel who are the standard-bearers of its teachings.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
“Much have they afflicted me
from my youth,”
let Israel now say.
“Much have they afflicted me
from my youth;
but also they have not prevailed against me.
The plowers plowed on my back;
they made long their furrows.
Adonoy is righteous,
He has cut the cords of the wicked.
Let them be ashamed and turned backward,
all haters of Zion.
Let them be as grass upon the roofs,
before it springs up it withers.
With which the reaper does not fill his hand,
nor the sheath binder his bosom.”
And the passers by did not say:
“The blessing of Adonoy be upon you;
“we bless you in the Name of Adonoy.”
Psalm 130

<small>In this Psalm the Jewish soul sings at the way the Jewish spirit ascends from the depths of the deepest misery of all, the burden of sin and guilt. “For with You is forgiveness, in order that You be feared,” for through repentance forgiveness is achieved, and thus it is a Song of Ascent.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
Out of the depths
I have called to You, Adonoy.
My Master, hear my voice;
let Your ears be attentive
to the voice of my supplications.
If You God should take account of iniquities,
my Master, who could survive?
For with You is forgiveness,
in order that You be feared.
I hope for Adonoy, my soul hopes;
and for His word, I wait
My soul [waits] for my Master
more than the watchman [waits]
for the morning,
[more than] the watchman [waits]
for the morning.
Wait, Israel, upon Adonoy
for with Adonoy there is loving-kindness
and with Him there is much redemption.
And He will redeem Israel
from all its iniquities.
Psalm 131
<small>This Psalm summarizes all the greatness of David's soul in three short verses.</small>
A Song of Ascents of David.
Adonoy, my heart was not haughty
nor my eyes lofty;
and I did not concern myself
with things too great
and too wonderful for me.
Have I not calmed
and quieted my soul,
like a child that is weaned from his mother,
like a weaned child my soul is with me.
Wait Israel upon Adonoy,
from now and forever.
Psalm 132

<small>David sings with joy at his appointment to make the preparations for the building of God's Holy Dwelling, and for God's promise that he and his descendants will be the eternal bearers of the royal kingdom of Israel.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
Remember, Adonoy, unto David
all his afflictions.
How he swore to Adonoy
and vowed to the Mighty One of Jacob.
Surely I will not enter
into the tent of my house;
nor will I go up
into the bed that is spread for me.
Surely I will not give sleep to my eyes,
nor slumber to my eyelids.
Until I find a place for Adonoy,
dwelling places for the Mighty One of Jacob.
Behold, we heard of it as being in Ephrath;
we found it in the fields of the forest.
Let us come to His Tabernacles,
let us prostrate ourselves at His footstool.
Arise Adonoy to Your resting place,
You and the Ark of Your strength.
Let Your priests
clothe themselves in righteousness,
and let Your devoted ones sing in joy.
For the sake of David Your servant,
do not reject Your annointed.
Adonoy swore to David,
a truth from which He will not turn back,
“Of the fruit of your womb
I will set upon your throne.
If your children will preserve My covenant
and My testimony that I will teach them;
then their children too
will forever sit on your throne.”
For Adonoy has chosen Zion;
He desired it for His Dwelling Place.
“This is My resting place forever,
here I will dwell for I have desired it.
Her provision I will abundantly bless;
her needy I will satiate with bread.
And her priests
I will clothe with deliverance
and her devoted ones will sing for joy.
There will I cause to spring up
the horn of David
[there] have I ordered a lamp
for my annointed.
His enemies I will clothe with shame,
but upon him his crown will shine.”
Psalm 133
<small>This Psalm portrays the bliss that awaits the nation of Israel when God will again cause His Divine Presence to rest among us—on the day we are reunited in our own land.</small>
A Song of Ascents of David.
Behold, how good and how pleasant it is
when brethren also dwell together in unity.
Like the precious oil upon the head
coming down upon the beard,
the beard of Aaron
that comes down
upon the edge of his garments.
Like the dew of Hermon
that comes down
upon the mountains of Zion;
for there Adonoy commanded the blessing,
life for evermore.
Psalm 134

<small>This Psalm calls us to rise up in our present night of exile, and pray for the restoration of the Holy Temple. These prayers preserve the spiritual bond which unites all of us and inspire us to remember Zion.</small>
A Song of Ascents.
Behold, bless Adonoy
all [you] servants of Adonoy,
who stand in the House of Adonoy
in the night.
Lift your hands to the Sanctuary
and bless Adonoy.
Adonoy will bless you out of Zion,
[He Who is] Maker of heaven and earth.

text.20_Maariv Service for the Conclusion of: Unlike the morning Shacharis and afternoon Mincha services which correspond to the two daily communal sacrifices (Tamid), offered in the Temple, one in the morning and one in the afternoon, the evening Maariv service has no counterpart in the Temple service, since sacrifices were never brought at night in the Temple.

The Maariv service was instituted to correspond to the Temple ritual of keeping on the altar the unconsumed parts of sacrifices that had been offered earlier in the day. These parts were kept on the altar at night so that they could be completely consumed by its fire. This ritual was applicable only if there actually were uncon- sumed parts of offerings.

Although the Maariv service was instituted to correspond to this ritual, and may therefore seem to be non-obligatory (see Maseches Berachos 27b), Rabbeinu Yitzchak Alfasi and all the other codifiers have ruled that Maariv has been accepted and hallowed by custom, and is therefore an obligatory service.

and does not arouse all His rage.1Psalms 78:38. This verse consists of thirteen Hebrew words. It recalls the “thirteen attributes of Divine mercy” (Exodus 34:6-7). In the evening when man pauses from the rush of his daily activities, he is conscious of having sinned during the day, and thus begins his prayer with this appeal for Divine mercy.—Machzor Vitry Midrash Tanchuma (Pinchos 13) notes that the morning sacrifice (תָּמִיד שֶׁל שַׁחַר) atoned for sins committed during the night, while the afternoon sacrifice (תָּמִיד שֶׁל בֵּין הָעַרְבַּיִם) atoned for sins committed during the day. Since the evening service does not represent Temple sacrifice, it became customary to recite this verse because it mentions that God “atones iniquity.”— Avudraham

The following prayer was originally a compilation of eighteen verses instituted during the Gaonic era as a substitute for the Shemoneh Esrei. According to Avudraham, the Shemoneh Esrei was omitted because of decrees issued against the Jews that banned them from participating in the Evening Service. text.22_Havdalah, 0_Paragraph: The Havdalah service, with which we conclude the observance of Shabbos was ordained by the Men of the Great Assembly who flourished through the beginning of the Second Temple period.
text.22_Havdalah, 1_Paragraph: You hold the wine cup in your right hand until after the blessing on the wine, then transfer the cup to your left hand and hold the spice box in your right for the blessing on the spices. Then set the spice box aside, return the wine cup to your right hand, and pronounce the blessing on the fire. After the blessing, set the wine cup down and look at your fingernails in the light of the candles. Afterwards take the wine cup in your right hand until you complete Havdalah.

text.24_Hallel, 0_Paragraph: Hallel, the name especially applied to Psalms 113-118, is mentioned in the Talmud (Pesachim 117a), when Rabbi Judah quoted Samuel as saying “Who recited this Hallel? (Who ordained that this Hallel be read?) The prophets ordained that Israel should recite Hallel when they are redeemed from misfortune as an expression of gratitude for their redemption.”
text.24_Hallel, 1_Paragraph: In time, the Rabbis made the reading of Hallel obligatory on the major festivals such as Pesach, Shavuos, and Sukkos. Since Maccabean times, Chanukah is like- wise marked by the reading of Hallel. On Purim the reading of the Scroll of Esther takes the place of Hallel. (Maseches Megillah 14a)
text.24_Hallel, 2_Paragraph: The reading of Hallel on Rosh Chodesh is not rabbinically ordained, but a minhag, a custom which began with the Jews of Babylon in the second century, and has been accepted by all Israel as an obligatory Service. Because it is a minor festival, the Hallel is shortened on Rosh Chodesh by omitting half of Psalms 115 and 116. On the last six days of Pesach also, only “half”-Hallel is recited to show that our joy is diminished because of the drowning of the Egyptians.
text.24_Hallel, 3_Paragraph: Hallel is omitted in a house of mourning (during the week of shiv'ah) on Rosh Chodesh and Chanukah.

text.24_Hallel, 269_Paragraph: On Rosh Chodesh and on Chol HaMoed the Chazzan recites the Whole Kaddish on page 000. On Chanukah (except for Rosh Chodesh-Chanukah and Shabbos-Chanukah) he recites the Half-Kaddish on page 000.
text.24_Hallel, 270_Paragraph: On Shabbos, Yom Tov and Hoshanah Rabbah the Service continues with the Order of Reading the Torah, on page 000. At other times turn to page 000 for the Order of Reading the Torah. After the conclusion of the Torah reading, אַשְׁרֵי (Fortunate), page 000, and וּבָא לְצִיוֹן (The Redeemer will come), page 000, are said. The Chazzan recites Half-Kaddish , the Tefillin are then removed and the Congregation says the Musaf Amidah on page 000. The Musaf Amidah for Chol HaMoed is found on page 000.

text.25_Prayers for Yom Tov, 0_Blessings on t: <small>Many recite the following prayer before taking the four species (Lulav).</small>
our God, King of the Universe
Who sanctified us with His commandments
concerning the taking of the lulav.
<small>If you are taking the lulav for the first time on Sukkos, you should also recite:</small>
our God, King of the Universe
Who has kept us alive and sustained us
and brought us to this time.

text.25_Prayers for Yom Tov, 2_Kiddush for Yo: <small>When Yom Tov occurs on Shabbos, begin here:</small>
And evening came, then morning came,
And the heavens and the earth were completed
And God completed, by the seventh day,
His work which He had done;
and He abstained on the seventh day
from all His work which He had done.
And God blessed the seventh day
which God had created to do.
Attention! Our masters and our teachers
our God, King of the Universe,
Creator of the fruit of the vine.
our God, King of the Universe,
Who takes bread out from the earth.
our God, King of the Universe
Who chose us from among all peoples,
and exalted us above all (tongues) languages,
and sanctified us with His commandments.
And [You] gave us Adonoy, our God,
the season of the giving of our Torah,
and Your appointed festivals of holiness
You gave us for a heritage.
<small>On the first night of Sukkos, the berachah לישב בסוכה , (p. 000) is recited before the following berachah. On the second night, the berachos are said in the sequence as printed.</small>
<small>(On the last two nights of Pesach the following berachah is omitted)</small>
our God, King of the Universe
Who has kept us alive and sustained us
and brought us to this season.
our God, King of the Universe
Who sanctified us with His commandments
and commanded us to dwell in the Sukkah.
<small>(When Yom Tov occurs at the conclusion of Shabbos, the following two berachos are said before the berachah of “ שֶׁהֶחֱיָנוּ , Who has kept us alive”):</small>
our God, King of the Universe,
Creator of the lights of fire.
our God, King of the Universe,
between the sacred and the unhallowed,
and the sanctity of Yom Tov
[from] the six work days You have sanctified.
Your people Israel with Your holiness.
Who distinguished between sacred and sacred.
text.25_Prayers for Yom Tov, 3_Amidah for Yom: and my mouth will declare Your praise.
our God, and God of our fathers,
God of Abraham, God of Isaac,
the Great, the Powerful, the Awesome,
Who remembers the piety of the Patriarchs,
for the sake of His Name, with love.
King, Helper, and Deliverer and Shield.
You are mighty forever, my Master;
You are the Resurrector of the dead
the powerful One to deliver us.
<small>(On Pesach except for Shacharis of the first day, on Shavuos and Sukkos including Shacharis of Shemini Atzeres say:</small>
He causes the dew to descend.
(From Mincha of Shemini Atzeres until after Shacharis on the first day of Pesach say:
Causer of the wind to blow
and of the rain to fall.)
<small>If you forgot to say this, see page 000.</small>
Sustainer of the living with kindliness,
Resurrector of the dead with great mercy,
to those who sleep in the dust.
Who is like You, Master of mighty deeds,
and who can be compared to You?
King Who causes death and restores life,
and causes deliverance to sprout forth.
to restore the dead to life.
<small>When praying silently, continue “You are holy” on page 000.</small>
<small>When the Chazzan repeats the Shemoneh Esrei during Shacharis, the Kedushah is said here. For Mincha turn to page 000.</small>
<small>The Congregation says and the Chazzan repeats:</small>
We will hallow and revere You
of the company of the holy Seraphim
as is written by the hand of Your prophet,
“And they called to one another and said:
the fullness of all the earth is His glory.'”
Facing them, they offer praise and say:
Then, with the sound of great rushing,
raising themselves up toward the Serafim,
Facing them, they offer praise and say:
From Your place, our King, You will appear
When will You reign in Zion?
You will be exalted and sanctified
for all generations and for all eternity.
May our eyes behold Your kingship,
as it is said in the songs of Your might
Your God, Zion, throughout all generations!
<small>The Congregation says and the Chazzan repeats:</small>
We will hallow and revere You
of the company of the holy Seraphim
as is written by the hand of Your prophet,
“And they called one to another, and said:
the fullness of all the earth is His glory.'”
Facing them, they offer praise and say:
And in Your Holy Words it is written:
Your God, Zion, throughout all generations!
You are holy and Your Name is holy
For a great and Almighty King—

You chose us from [among] all the peoples;1All three pilgrimage festivals are alluded to in this prayer. “You chose us from among all peoples,” etc. refers to Pesach, when God redeemed us from Egypt and took us to Himself for a people. (See Exodus 6:7)
You loved us and took pleasure in us;
You exalted us above all tongues,2“You exalted us above all tongues” etc. refers to Shavuos when we received the Torah which sanctified us above all nations with its commandments.
You drew us near, our King, to Your servitude,
and Your great and holy Name

You have pronounced upon us.3We were drawn near to Him and His Name was proclaimed upon us on Sukkos with the עַנַנֵּי כָּבוֹד , the Divine clouds that hovered over Israel and signified God’s protection and forgiveness.
<small>When the Festival falls on Motzoei Shabbos say:</small>
You have made known to us, Adonoy, our God,
and have taught us to perform
And [You] gave us, Adonoy our God,
upright judgments and teachings of truth,
statutes and commandments that are good.
You have given us as a heritage
and4Voluntary-offerings refer to the “appearance-offerings,” עוֹלַת רְאִיָּה , which one could bring as often as he appeared in the Temple, during the Festival. festivals for voluntary-offerings;
and the feasts of the pilgrimage festival.
between the sacred and the unhallowed,
and the sanctity of Yom Tov
[from] the six work days You have sanctified.
Your people Israel with Your holiness.
And [You] gave us Adonoy, our God,
the season of the giving of the Torah,
Our God and God of our fathers,
may there ascend, come, and reach,
the son of David, Your servant;
and the remembrance of Your entire people,
the House of Israel, before You
be mindful of us on this day for blessing,
and deliver us for good life.
In accord with the promise of deliverance
have compassion on us and deliver us;
for to You our eyes are directed
Who is King, Gracious and Merciful.

And load us5The translation of וְהַשִׂאֵנוּ is based on Avudraham who quotes the verse, אֵלֶה מַשָׂא בְּנֵי קְהָת , “This is the load of the sons of Kehos.” (Numbers 4:15) Avudraham offers an alternative translation based on the verse, וַיִּשָּׂא מַשְׂאת , “And he sent portions (gifts),” (Genesis 43:34), which would render the prayer, “Send us as a gift the blessing of Your appointed seasons.” up
with the blessing of Your appointed seasons
and You promised to bless us.6For Adonoy, your God, will bless you through all your crops, and through all the work of your hands.—Deuteronomy 16:15
Our God and God of our fathers:
and give us a share in Your Torah,
and gladden our souls with Your deliverance,

and purify our hearts to serve You in truth,7Even though the choice of being righteous and God-fearing was given to man, nevertheless, we ask God to help us achieve these goals we seek to attain. Our Sages have said, “ הַבָּא לְטַהֵר מְסַייעִין אוֹתוֹ . He who reaches to the decision to purify himself, is afforded Divine assistance” which enables him to achieve purity in serving God. (Yoma 38b)— Avudraham
and give us as a heritage, Adonoy, our God,
and may Israel rejoice in You—
[they who are] sanctifiers of Your Name.
the Sabbath, and)8When a Festival falls on Shabbos, Shabbos is mentioned before Yom Tov because the Jews were given Shabbos before they received the Festivals.—Pesher Davar
Israel and the seasons.9God sanctified the Jewish people, who in turn were charged with responsibility to set the time of the Festivals and thus they sanctified the Festivals.—Etz Yosef
with Your people Israel and their prayer,
to the Holy of Holies in Your abode,
and accept their prayer, lovingly and willingly.
And may You always find pleasure
with the service of Your people, Israel.
Who returns His Divine Presence to Zion.
At the words,We are thankful, bend forward; at Adonoy return to an upright position.
that You Adonoy are our God
and the God of our fathers forever;
our Rock, Rock of our lives,
We will give thanks to You
which are committed into Your hand.
And for our souls which are entrusted to You,
and for Your miracles of every day with us
and for Your wonders and benefactions
for Your compassion is never withheld;
we have always placed our hope in You.
(When the Chazzan repeats the Shemoneh Esrei and says, “Who returns His Divine Presence to Zion”, the congregation responds by saying “Amein” and then the following prayer.)
that You Adonoy are our God
Our Creator, Creator of the Beginning.
to Your great and holy Name
for keeping us alive, and sustaining us;
so may You always keep us alive
to the Courtyards of Your Sanctuary
for we are thankful to You.
to Whom all thanks are due.
And all the living shall thank You forever
Your great Name with sincerity forever;
the Almighty, Who is our deliverance
and You it is fitting to praise.
<small>To be said by the Chazzan at Shacharis Priestly Blessings</small>

with the threefold blessing of the Torah,
written by the hand of Moses, Your servant,

upon us and upon all Israel, Your people.

a Torah of life and the love of kindliness,

and to bless Your people Israel,
at all times and at every moment

Adonoy, my Rock and my Redeemer.

and let my soul be like dust to all.

Adonoy, my God and God of my fathers,
that no person be envious of me
and that I not be envious of others,

and save me from the evil inclination,

unify Your Name in Your world,
rebuild Your city, establish Your house
redeem Your people, rejoice Your congregation).
Act for the sake of Your Name.
Act for the sake of Your right hand.
Act for the sake of Your Torah.
Act for the sake of Your holiness.
In order that Your loved ones be released,
deliver [with] Your right hand and answer me.
<small>Biblical phrases applicable to one's name may be found on pp. 000-000.</small>
and the thoughts of my heart—before You
Adonoy, my Rock and my Redeemer.
upon us and upon all Israel
Adonoy, our God, and the God of our Fathers
that the Holy Temple be rebuilt
and grant us our share in Your Torah.
And there we will serve You reverently
as in the days of old,
with the offerings of Judah and Jerusalem

<small>At the Minchah and Maariv services, the Chazzan recites the Whole Kaddish on page 000. The congregation says עָלֵינוּ on page 000, and mourners recite Kaddish on page 000.</small>

<small>On the first two nights of Pesach, some congregations recite הַלֵל on page 000, and then continue as above. On the second night of Pesach, the Counting of the Omer, page 000, is said, and then continue עָלֵינוּ as above.</small>
<small>On Sukkos, לְדָוִד ה' , page 000, is said after עָלֵינוּ .</small>
On Friday night, וַיְכֻלוּ , page 000 is recited before the Chazzan recites the Whole Kaddish.
<small>At Shacharis, הַלֵל , page 000, is said. The Chazzan then recites the Whole Kaddish, and the service continues with the Order of the Reading of the Torah on page 000.</small>

Even though the kohanim are commanded to bless Israel every day (according to some authorities) nevertheless, the custom outside the Holy Land is that koha- nim bless the people only during the Musaf Service of the Festivals, and the High Holidays. One reason given is that the Priestly Blessings are pronounced only in a festive atmosphere. Thus on weekdays when people are troubled with the difficul- ties of earning a livelihood, and even on the Sabbath when people are disturbed by thoughts of their economic plight, the blessings are not pronounced.
<small>During the Musaf Service of the Festivals, however, which precedes the festive meal of the holiday, a joyous atmosphere does prevail and the Priestly Blessing is pronounced.</small>
After the Chazzan's recital of ‘ רְצֵה , be pleased,' the following prayer is recited by the Congregation and kohanim, and repeated by the Chazzan:
May our prayer be sweet before You

as a burnt-offering and as a sacrifice.15The burnt-offering refers to the עוֹלַת הַתָּמִיד , the daily communal burnt-offering, while sacrifice refers to the מוּסַף , the additional offerings of the Festivals.— Iyun Tefiloh According to Dover Shalom these two types of offerings can be compared to two kinds of prayers. The truly pious Jew is concerned only with serving his Creator and his prayers are offered entirely to God. He asks nothing for himself. His prayers are similar to a burnt-offering which is consumed in its entirety on God’s altar. Not every Jew is capable of such a lofty degree of Divine service. Many serve God but are conscious of their own personal needs and desires. Their prayer is thus similar to a שְׁלָמִים , peace offering, of which only part is consumed on the altar, the owner also being permitted to eat and enjoy part of it. We pray that both kinds of prayers be pleasing and acceptable to God, as were the sacrifices on the altar.

text.27_Counting the Omer, 0_Paragraph: <small>The Omer is counted from the second night of Passover until the night before Shavuos. The counting of forty-nine days (seven weeks) between the Festival of Passover and Shavuos (the Feast of Weeks), connects the exodus from Egypt with the festival of the giving of the Torah. Just as one who awaits a most intimate friend on a certain day counts the days in eager anticipation of his arrival, so do we count the days from our liberation till the day we receive the Torah, which is the culmination and fulfillment of our freedom.</small>

text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 121_: to guard you in all your ways.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 122_: They will carry you upon their hands,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 123_: lest you hurt your foot on a rock.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 124_: You will tread upon lion and snake,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 125_: you will trample young lion and serpent.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 126_: Because he clings to Me with desire,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 128_: I will strengthen him, for he knows My Name.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 129_: When he calls upon Me, I will answer him;
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 130_: I am with him in distress,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 131_: I will free him and honor him.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 132_: I will satiate him with longevity,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 133_: and will let him see My deliverance.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 134_: I will satiate him with longevity
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 135_: and will let him see My deliverance.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 137_: Adonoy, how many are my tormentors;7Psalm 3 was sung by David when, at the age of 65, he had to flee his son Absalom.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 142_: But You, Adonoy, are a shield for me;
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 143_: my glory and Raiser of my head.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 144_: With my voice, I call out to Adonoy,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 145_: and He answers me from His holy mountain,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 148_: I awake for Adonoy supports me.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 149_: I fear not the tens of thousands of people
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 150_: deployed against me from every side.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 151_: Rise Adonoy, deliver me, my God,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 152_: for You have struck all my enemies8David is confident of God’s help, because God has always smitten his enemies.—Radak
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 154_: You have broken the teeth of the wicked.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 156_: upon Your people is Your blessing, selah.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 157_: Adonoy, our God, make us lie down in peace,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 160_: Spread over us the shelter of Your peace,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 161_: and direct us to better ourselves
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 163_: and deliver us speedily for Your Name's sake.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 164_: Shield us, and remove from us
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 167_: Remove the adversary from before us
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 169_: and in the shadow of Your wings shelter us.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 171_: Who is our protector and rescuer.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 173_: Who is King, Gracious, and Merciful.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 174_: Guard our going out and our coming in
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 179_: Blessed is Adonoy when we lie down
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 180_: Blessed is Adonoy when we rise.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 182_: are the souls of the living and the dead,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 183_: (as it is written): For in His hand
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 184_: is the soul of every living thing
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 185_: and the spirit of every human being.9Job 12:10
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 186_: In Your hand, I commit my spirit;
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 190_: reveal the unity of Your Name,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 192_: and reign over us forever and ever.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 194_: may our heart rejoice and our soul exalt
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 196_: when it will be said to Zion:
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 197_: Your God has begun His reign
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 198_: Adonoy is King, Adonoy was King,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 199_: Adonoy will reign forever and ever
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 201_: and to all eternity, You will reign in glory,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 202_: for we have no king except You.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 203_: The angel who redeemed me from all evil10These are the words used by Jacob when he blessed Joseph, and his sons Ephraim and Menashe.—Genesis 48:16
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 205_: and may they be called by my name
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 206_: and the names of my fathers,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 208_: and may they multiply like fish
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 210_: And He said, “If you will diligently heed
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 211_: the voice of Adonoy, your God,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 212_: and do what is upright in His eyes,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 213_: and listen carefully to His commandments,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 217_: I will not put upon you,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 218_: for I am Adonoy, your Healer.11Exodus 15:26
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 223_: for is this one not a firebrand
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 224_: plucked out of the fire?”12Zechariah 3:2
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 226_: Sixty mighty men [are set] around it,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 227_: of the mighty men of Israel.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 228_: All of them armed with swords,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 230_: each man has his sword at his side,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 231_: because of the dread of the night.13Song of Songs 3:7,8
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 232_: <small>Each unit until “A song of ascents,” is said three times:</small>
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 233_: Adonoy bless you and guard you!
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 234_: Adonoy shine His countenance upon you
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 236_: Adonoy turn His countenance toward you
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 237_: and grant you peace!14Numbers 6:24-26
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 238_: Behold, He neither slumbers nor sleeps!
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 239_: the Guardian of Israel.15Psalms 121:4
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 240_: For your deliverance, I hope, Adonoy;16Genesis 49:18
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 241_: I hope, Adonoy, for Your deliverance;
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 242_: Adonoy, for Your deliverance I hope.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 243_: In the Name of Adonoy, God of Israel:
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 248_: and above my head, the Presence of Almighty.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 251_: Fortunate are all who fear Adonoy,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 253_: When you eat of the toil of your hands
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 254_: you are fortunate and it is good with you.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 255_: Your wife will be like a fruitful vine
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 256_: in the innermost parts of your house;
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 259_: Behold! thus shall be blessed the man
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 262_: and [may you] see the good of Jerusalem
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 263_: all the days of your life!
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 269_: commune with your hearts upon your bed,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 270_: and be silent, selah!18Psalms 4:5
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 271_: Master of the Universe Who reigned
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 273_: At the time when all was made by His will,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 274_: then was His Name proclaimed King.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 275_: And after all things shall cease to be
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 276_: the Awesome One will reign alone.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 278_: and He shall be in glory.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 279_: He is One, and there is no second
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 280_: to compare to Him, to associate [with Him].
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 283_: He is my God and my ever-living Redeemer,
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 284_: the Rock of my destiny in times of distress.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 285_: He is my flag and my refuge;
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 286_: He is the portion of my cup on the day I call.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 287_: Into His hand I entrust my spirit
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 288_: [both] when I sleep and when I awaken.
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 289_: And with my spirit my body [too],
text.28_Prayer Before Retiring at Night, 290_: Adonoy is with me, I shall not fear.
